Award.AwardTitle: Theory of mechanochemical phenomena in molecular and bio-molecular systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dmitrii E. Makarov is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division to develop and employ computer simulations and theory to study the coupling between mechanical and chemical phenomena in biological and synthetic molecular systems. The research focuses on rational design of novel mechano-sensitive molecular systems, characterization of multidimensional free energy landscapes of mechanically stressed biomolecules, and theory of dissipative phenomena in proteins. The award is cofunded by the Condensed Matter and Materials Theory program in the Division of Materials Research.


This research advances our understanding of the interplay between mechanical and chemical forces in living organisms, which accounts for structural integrity of tissues and bone, enables organisms' defense against various diseases and lies at the heart of many vital biological phenomena. It may further impact bottom-up design of novel polymeric and bio-polymeric materials with unique mechanical properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcomes of this research project are as follows:

1. The Makarov group and their collaborators have developed a comprehensive theory, along with computational tools, that allow one to predict how molecules respond when mechanical forces are applied to them. Pulling on individual molecules mechanically is known to induce novel chemical transformations, but prediction of such phenomena has been largely based on trial and error or on chemical intuition. The theoretical tools developed by this research allow chemists to design novel “mechanophores” (i.e. molecules whose chemical properties are changed by mechanical forces) computationally.

2. When a piece of material is bent or squeezed, individual molecules within this material experience a mechanical force, which may change their chemical properties. This, in turn, may lead to a change in the material’s physical properties (such as its color or its resistance to fracture). Theoretical and computational studies carried out as part of this project have provided important insights into how macroscopic forces applied to a bulk sample are transmitted to individual molecules. These insights enable bottom-up design of smart materials, whose mechanical properties are programmed by the arrangement of their constituent individual molecules.

3. In single-molecule pulling experiments, mechanical and chemical properties of individual molecules (particularly biomolecules such as DNA and proteins) can be probed one molecule at a time. However, the intrinsic molecular properties may be affected by the experimental setup. For example, in optical or magnetic tweezers studies, the motion of an individual molecule is monitored by measuring the position of a much larger, micrometer-sized bead attached to the molecule, but the very fact of being attached to such a large object slows down the motion of the molecule of interest. The Makarov group has developed a theoretical method allowing one to estimate how much intrinsic molecular properties are changed by the experimental setup; moreover, intrinsic molecular properties (i.e. ones in the absence of the instrument) can be back calculated from the experimental data using this method.

4. To understand how quickly proteins can attain their biologically relevant structure or find their targets within cells, it is necessary to know the magnitude and tyhe nature of the friction forces experienced by those molecules. Such friction forces result from the molecules’ interaction with the solvent (i.e. water) and from the interaction of a molecule with itself. The latter type of friction, known as internal friction, has long been a controversial subject, with the precise molecular mechanisms leading to internal friction poorly understood. A key outcome of this project is establishing that internal friction in proteins largely results from crankshaft-like rotational motions within a polypeptide chain. This microscopic view of internal friction provides a justification for the simple theoretical model of protein dynamics known as the Rouse/Zimm model with internal friction. This model was further shown to provide a comprehensive description of data from both single-molecule measurements of protein dynamics and from molecular simulations.

5. This project has trained several postdoctoral researches and graduate students, as well as an undergraduate student. All of the projects that the group members pursued were highly multidisciplinary and involved close collaborations with experimental groups and with other computational researchers and theoreticians. Interdisciplinary Molecular Biophysics seminar series at UT Austin and the UT Biophysics day provided a venue for the group members to share their research with their peers and with internationally renowned visitors.

The PI has co-organized and co-taught two summer schools: the Molecular Kinetics School in Telluride, CO, and the CECAM Molecular Kinetics School in Lausanne, Switzerland. The schools were attended by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers with diverse backgrounds and from many countries. The PI also co-organized a Telluride Biophysical Dynamics Workshop and the UT Austin Biophysics Day. 

The results were published in highly visible, peer reviewed research journals (such as Journal of Chemical Physics, Journal of the American Chemical Society, Journal of Physical Chemistry, Scientific Reports, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Protein Science) and reported in numerous presentations that the PI and the group members have given at UT Austin, at other Universities and at national and international workshops and conferences.  The computer codes developed by the group are available to other researchers through the group's website.
